properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total snowfall: 20 to 40 cm possible. Locations: Hopedale and vicinity, Postville - Makkovik. Time span: overnight tonight until Thursday morning. Remarks: The snow will be accompanied by strong north to northeasterly winds gusting up to 70 km/h on Wednesday giving reduced visibilities in blowing snow. Winds will further increase from the north to northwest Wednesday night, with gusts of 100 to 130 km/h possible, causing blizzard like conditions. As a result, this watch is likely to be upgraded to a warning in subsequent forecasts later today. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-13T01:31:06-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T09:32:06-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0482793089.2019
Area: Postville - Makkovik, Hopedale and vicinity

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall is expected. Total rainfall: 50 to 80 mm Locations: southwestern Newfoundland from Channel-Port aux Basques to Grey River. Time span: late this morning until midday on Wednesday. Remarks: After a brief period of snow this morning, precipitation is expected to transition to rain at times heavy late in the morning. Rain is forecast to continue through tonight before tapering off Wednesday morning. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall is expected. Total rainfall: 35 to 55 mm. Locally higher amounts possible over higher terrain. Locations: Bay St. George up to the Bay of Islands Time span: Tuesday afternoon until early Wednesday afternoon. Remarks: After 5 to 10 cm snow today, precipitation is expected to transition to rain this afternoon. Warm temperatures and rain will combine to cause any existing snow pack to melt and may contribute to water pooling. Rain is forecast to continue though Tuesday night before transitioning to flurries Wednesday afternoon. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Periods of rain have begun across the Island and will continue until late overnight tonight. Total rainfall accumulations up to 25 millimetres are forecast, although it is possible that higher amounts may fall in localized areas. The rain is expected to change to flurries early Wednesday morning as cold westerly winds move into the region and temperatures quickly fall below freezing. Driving conditions may become difficult as the cold air and flurries move in. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-13T04:42:49-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Approaching storm will give mixed precipitation today into Wednesday morning. Light snow began over the Islands early this morning and has started to change over to rain. The rain is expected to become intermittent this afternoon, then redevelop tonight and continue into Wednesday morning. Total accumulations of 20 to 30 millimetres are currently forecast. Flurries are expected to begin by Wednesday afternoon, as brisk westerly winds usher in colder temperatures. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls possible this afternoon. Flurries and local snow squalls are expected to begin this afternoon and continue into Wednesday. Local snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm per 12 hours are possible along with local blowing snow reducing visibilities to near zero. Local snow squalls are forecast to taper off when the winds shift to southwest on Wednesday. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall amounts: 5 to 15 cm, highest amounts inland. Locations: Cartwright and south to L'Anse-au-Clair. Time span: This afternoon through to Wednesday morning. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, will develop this afternoon along the Labrador Straits and spread northward, reaching Cartwright this evening. The snow will then transition to rain from south to north overnight into Wednesday morning with a period of freezing rain likely over inland areas. Highest snowfall accumulations are expected inland and over higher terrain, particularly along the Trans-Labrador Highway, where temperatures will be slower to rise. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Arctic air remains entrenched in the central interior as a frontal system crosses the BC Interior, delivering warm moist air aloft. Conditions are favourable for freezing rain mixed at times with ice pellets or snow. Freezing rain and ice pellets are forecast to change to rain showers by noon as warm air reaches the surface and brings temperatures above the freezing mark. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-12T19:59:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T12:25:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3564335748.2019

Snow will be accompanied with north to northeasterly winds gusting to 50 or 60 km/h, resulting in blowing snow over exposed areas. Over eastern areas of the Trans-Labrador Highway in the Eagle River forecast region, a period of freezing rain is expected Wednesday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Rain is forecast to continue until Wednesday morning, with total forecast rainfall accumulations ranging from 40 to 60 millimetres over the region. Over higher terrain, snow will change to rain this morning as temperatures rise. Rain is expected to change to flurries on Wednesday morning as cold westerly winds move across the province. Flurries are likely to persist through the day on Wednesday and into Wednesday night, when conditions may become favourable for the development of snow squalls. The travelling public are urged to prepare for potentially difficult driving conditions in snow tonight and Tuesday morning. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Snow, ice pellets, freezing rain and rain today. Snow will change over to ice pellets and freezing rain and then to rain this morning. Over the Bathurst area, the rain may be mixed with snow. The rain will change back to snow tonight and then taper off overnight. Additional snowfall amounts of 5 to 15 cm are expected today. The travelling public are urged to prepare for potentially difficult driving conditions in the snow and mixed precipitation. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake Effect snow squalls continue today. Flurries and local snow squalls will continue to affect the area this morning and early this afternoon before moving out of the region in the late afternoon. Additional snowfall amounts of 20 to 30 cm are expected by late afternoon, with local blowing snow reducing visibilities to near zero at times. Travel is expected to be hazardous and squalls will have a significant impact on the morning commute. Local snow squalls are expected to taper off when the wind shifts to the northwest this evening. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls expected Wednesday. Southerly winds over the relatively warm waters of Lake Superior are expected to produce flurries and local snow squalls on Wednesday. The squalls could start as early as Wednesday morning and are expected to continue through Wednesday night. Local snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are possible on Wednesday, however areas closer to Lake Superior could see locally higher amounts of 15 to 25 cm. Additional amounts of 5 to 15 cm are possible Wednesday night into Thursday morning. Local blowing snow reducing visibilities will also be a concern. Local snow squalls are forecast to taper off when the winds shift to the northwest on Thursday. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Ice build-up due to freezing rain is expected or occurring. Light northerly outflow winds continue to bring modified arctic air through mainland valleys as a Pacific frontal system crosses the region. The combination of warm air from the approaching system overriding the cold outflow is producing freezing rain in valleys throughout the region. Freezing rain will persist until late this morning when temperatures finally rise above zero. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Ice build-up may cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-12T21:32:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T12:37:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2381145712.2019
Area: North Coast - inland including Terrace
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Higher than normal water levels with large waves are expected near the coast. Warning of potential breaking sea conditions and overwash issued jointly by Fisheries and Oceans Canada (Science) and the Meteorological Service of Canada - Quebec Region on 2019-11-11. An intense low pressure system will generate strong northeasterly winds over the areas listed below. The combination of these winds and the current run of medium-amplitude tidal ranges may produce minor breaking sea conditions along the coast near the following localities, on the dates and at the times specified (Eastern Standard Time). Rimouski - Mont-Joli: 2019-11-12, from 12:00 PM to 4:00 PM. Matane: 2019-11-12, from 12:00 PM to 4:00 PM. Forillon Park - Gaspé - Percé: 2019-11-12, 11:30 AM to 03:30 PM. Baie-Comeau: 2019-11-12, from 11:30 AM to 03:30 PM. Sept-Îles - Port-Cartier: 2019-11-12, from 11:30 AM to 03:30 PM. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-13T01:21:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T09:22:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4103265867.2019
Area: Mont-Joli area, Le Bic - Rimouski area, Matane, Forillon National Park - Gaspé area, Percé area, Baie-Comeau, Baie-Trinité area, Sept-Îles - Port-Cartier area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A snowstorm is expected. Total snowfall amounts of 20 to 40 centimetres are expected over these areas by Wednesday afternoon. Snow will be accompanied by strong winds reducing visibilities in blowing snow. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-13T01:25:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-12T09:26:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0571711373.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls today through Wednesday morning. Flurries and local snow squalls continue and are expected to persist into Wednesday morning. Local snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are possible today and amounts of near 15 cm are possible tonight into Wednesday morning. Local blowing snow reducing visibilities to near zero will also be a concern. Local snow squalls are forecast to taper off when the winds shift to southwest Wednesday afternoon. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-13T05:22:24-00:00
